content: Anyone under the misapprehension that Lotus might be moving away from 'performance through lightweight' philosophy, only needed to take a ride in the new Elise Club Racer announced in February of 2011, to know that this was definitely not the case. The engineers at Lotus put the lightest car of their current range on a diet, and managed to shed a further 24 kg. So how did they manage to make one of the lightest models on the market even lighter? The engineers behind the Elise Club Racer took a stripped-to-the-bare-bone approach, emphasized by the body-colored seats, but materialized in many other ways, such as the motorsport-derived lightweight battery and the deletion of certain standard factory-fitted components such as carpets, radio, and speakers, passenger footrest, central locking, mud flaps, and noise insulation. Attention to even the smallest of details ensured that Lotus' passion for performance through lightweight was translated throughout the car. For the first time ever, an Elise variant came complete with a Sport setting for the DPM (Dynamic Performance Management), allowing even the less experienced sports car drivers to feel at the top of their game, while the ability to switch it off completely pleased the more established drivers.
